div.p:
As we are in daily expectation of the
arrival of your better half we feel as if the worse
did not deserve a letter ᅳ This is plain enough is it
not? It is perhaps rather a sort of nervousness
produced by stretching our necks frequently to
see if the waggonwagon is in sight that quite indisposes
us to write. We wish heartily she would come
& relieve our suspense May be after all she
is single at supper giving the meat two
taps with her knife before she cuts it by way
of alagaing it to make it more digestible

A report furnished by Mr Lauga respecting
the party of Mr Arkwright & Christie made us
think a little. We saw nothing improper in
their conduct while proceeding Northward and
now that MrA.Arkwright returns We have neither seen
nor heard anything which induces us to believe
MrL.Lauga's report as having originated in him
MrA.Arkwright has been here three days & neither he nor
his people have shewnshown any disposition towards
illicit intercourse. He is the son of a clergyman

& if there is truth in what MrL.Lauga mentioned it must
have been perpetrated by Christie & not by Arkwright
the latter I believe abstains from traveling on
Sunday in accordance with a request of Mr
Ashton and if he has so much respect for
a missionary as to accede in one particular
he surely would not be guilty attempting to take
a prostitute into his company a deed he knows
would soon be published over the whole
country. We have found him agreeable & kind
& he has during his whole sojourn here behaved
like a gentleman I say this much because
I feel it would be unfair to condemn any one
unless the evidence is pretty strong & decided. Both
MrA.Arkwright & MrCh.Christie have English servants who have
been soldiers. They may have given occassionoccasion
to the report above referred to

We go on much as usual. Walls of school
six feet high ᅳ Measurement 48 by 20 ᅳ this morning
Hope to finish it this month ᅳ We have much better
soil for building where the school is than we had
in this house - A pie came last week & passed
on to the Bamangwato ᅳ All is peace But we are
sorry to hear a report of Cumming lying ill at the
Bakaas ᅳ Hope it is not true ᅳ Paul was in

jeopardy last week: two Buffaloes attacked a party cutting
reeds & after trying in vain to lift two Bakwanas from
the ground ran off ᅳ the men were hurt but will
recover the guns were at a distance & they had no trees
A Hottentot is left here with a broken thigh bone
For two things I can feel toothache & broken bones
MrA.Arkwright presented me with an excellent gun in its case &c.
He has shewnshown great likeability & is very thankful for
very small favours ᅳ Brunghere to do all the good we
can it is pleasant to meet here & there with those
who feel that we are of some use ᅳ The Land is
full of Griquas seeking their new location
alias filling their bellies with Eland fat No new
information respecting the boersBoers ᅳ except that they
are anxious to know where Mosilikatse is in order
to attack him ordered Sechele to send men to advise
Sekhonia to find it out for them ᅳ This Sechele does not
feel disposed to do

I send to you three full grown fruits of the
Mōana kindly brough by Mr Arkwright. Will
you when convenient send them & the Thama
to India? The Roots of the Thama dry up &
will not keep

Am happy to hear you proceed with the translation
Will you put P. I. above Isaiah as I. H.
above Sehela 49 I always laugh when I think
of my hymns. Spelled the new way too sharing the

fate of Pharaoh's fat kine ᅳ they were devoured by
the lean ones & yet the ill-favoured are the worst in all
the land of Egypt still. Something of the sort will
happen if yours & his are brought with coaptation
How will the following motion in next Com.Committee do
"that as certain friends of MrL.Lauga ignorant of the
fact that he took no part in the translation of the
new testament have produced the impression in
the country that he has not recievedreceived his full share
of the honours belonging thereto, We now avoid
the production of a similar impression by
referring his translation of Isaiah to the Judgements
of our esteemed bretherenbrethren of the French Society"
Translate Isaiah by all means & five have
nothing else we can at least compare ᅳ I cannot
see that you should take any notice of his
doings ᅳ If his own bretherenbrethrenwontwon't print it for
him why should we? Will bad translations please
us more easily than them?

Is no protest to be entered against the keeping
back of the Directors letter. Was it not con-
-cocted thus by E. R. & I. The third triumvirate
I feel inclined to abandon the ComCommittee as a
root of Rotteness - We shall write by
Plaid on & its well - They will soon be here
Our date tree has come up & we expect more
